1. Secure the Crime Scene \na) First priority is medical assistance to individuals and arresting the perpetrator. \nb) Ropes or barricades and guards will prevent unauthorized access to the area. c) The lead investigator evaluates the scene and determines the boundaries. They do an initial walkthrough and develop a strategy. d) All items must be documented and photographed.
2. Recording the Crime Scene Methods of crime-scene recording: photography, videography, sketches, and note-making.
a) Photography and Videography i. The crime scene should be unaltered, unless injured people are involved, objects must not be moved until they have been photographed from all necessary angles. ii. If things are removed, added, or positions changed the photographs may not be admissible evidence. iii. Photograph the area where crime took place and the adjacent areas at various angles and ranges. iv. If crime scene includes a body: 1. Take photos to show body’s location and position relative to the whole crime scene 2. Take close-up photos of injuries and weapons lying near the body 3. After the body is removed, photograph the surface underneath. 4. When size is significant, use a ruler or other measuring scale 5. Digital cameras allow for enhancement and examination in fine detail.
b) Sketching i. Once photos are taken, sketch the scene. ii. A Rough Sketch is a sketch, drawn at the crime scene, that contains an accurate depiction of the dimensions of the scene and shows the location of all objects having a bearing on the case. iii. All measurements are made with a tape measure iv. Show all items of physical evidence v. Assign each item a number or letter and list it in the legend vi. Show a compass heading designating north vii. A Finished sketch is a precise rendering of the crime scene, usually drawn to scale. viii. Computer-aided drafting (CAD) has become the standard.
c) Note-Making i. Note-making must be a constant activity throughout the processing of the crime scene. ii. The notes may be the only source of information to refresh memory. iii. Tape-recording notes at a scene can be advantageous – detailed notes can be taped much faster than they can be written.
3. Searching the Crime Scene a) One person should supervise and coordinate. b) Include all probable entry and exit points in search c) What to search for will be determined by the particular circumstances of the crime.
4. Collecting Physical Evidence a) Physical evidence can be anything from massive objects to microscopic traces. b) It may be necessary to take custody of all clothing worn by the participants in a crime. c) Handle carefully and wrap separately to avoid loss of trace evidence. d) Critical areas of the crime scene should be vacuumed and the sweepings submitted to the lab for analysis. e) Mobile crime-scene vehicles carry supplies to protect the crime scene; photo, collect, and package evidence; and develop latent fingerprints. f) The integrity of evidence is best maintained when the item is kept in its original condition as found at the crime scene. g) The entire object should be sent to the lab. h) If evidence is found adhering to a large structure, remove specimen with forceps or other appropriate tool. i) In the case of a bloodstain, one may either scrape the stain off the surface, transfer the stain to a moistened swab, or cut out the area of the object containing the stain. j) Each different item or similar items collected at different locations must be placed in separate containers. k) Packaging evidence separately prevents damage through contact and prevents cross-contamination.
5. Tools for Evidence Collection a) Forceps b) Plastic pill bottles c) Manila envelopes, glass vials, pill boxes d) Paper bags and plastic bags e) Fire evidence must be kept in an airtight container to prevent evaporation of petroleum residues f) Clothing must be air-dried and placed in individual paper bags.
6. Standard/Reference Samples a) The examination of evidence often requires comparison with a known standard/reference sample. b) A standard/reference sample is physical evidence whose origin is known, such as blood or hair from a suspect, that can be compared to crime scene evidence. c) Such materials may be obtained from the victim, a suspect, or other known sources. d) The presence of standard/reference samples greatly facilitates the work of the forensic scientist. e) Bloodstained evidence must be accompanied by a whole-blood or buccal swab s/r sample obtained from all relevant crime-scene participants. f) A buccal swab is a swab of the inner cheek, performed to collect cells for use in determining the DNA profile of an individual. g) Some types of evidence must also be accompanied by the collection of substrate controls. h) Normally collected at arson scenes. i) A substrate control is uncontaminated surface material close to an area where physical evidence has been deposited; used to ensure that the surface on which a sample has been deposited does not interfere with laboratory tests.
7. Submitting Evidence to the Lab a) Evidence is submitted to the lab either by personal delivery or by mail shipment. b) Most labs require that an evidence submission form accompany all evidence submitted. c) Enables the lab analyst to make an intelligent and complete examination of the evidence. d) Provide a brief description of the case history so the examiner can analyze in a logical sequence. e) The particular kind of examination requested for each type of evidence should be delineated. f) A list of all items submitted must be included.
